FeedItems.Title: Happy 10th Birthday, NuGet!
FeedItems.Summary: NuGet 1.0 was released on January 13th, 2011 ‚Äì 10 years and 4 major version releases ago. Since then, NuGet.org has grown to host a large and vibrant package ecosystem with over 230 thousand unique...

FeedItems.Title: Custom V2 OData queries will be deprecated March 9, 2021
FeedItems.Summary: We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (#37) last year and conducted a dry run in early November to ensure that there are no surprises for users. Going forward, we plan to bring all...

FeedItems.Title: Getting Started With NuGet 5.8
FeedItems.Summary:
Getting started with NuGet 5.8
NuGet 5.8 is included in Visual Studio 16.8 and .NET 5.0 out of the box. You can also download NuGet 5.8 for Windows, macOS, and Linux as a standalone executable.
NuGet...

FeedItems.Title: Advanced search on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that NuGet.org now supports one of our top customer asks – advanced search! You can now use a multitude of sorting and filtering criteria to help find the best NuGet...

FeedItems.Title: NuGet.org will permanently remove support for TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on June 15th

FeedItems.Title: NuGet.org will continue to support TLS 1.0 and 1.1 until further notice
FeedItems.Summary: Last November, we shared our two-stage plan for deprecating TLS 1.0/1.1 on NuGet.org and actions you can take today to ensure your systems use TLS 1.2. In that post, we announced that NuGet.org would...

co-authored by Scott Bommarito
At Microsoft, using the latest and secure encryption techniques is very important to us to ensure the security and privacy of our customers. TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1,...

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add a standardised entry for clarifying pricing/limitations for commercial packages." (#8427) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
It is not easy to distinguish whether the package is free or commercial just seeing the package description UI in Visual Studio. I would have to visit the company's website and look for pages that has pricing or purchasing information, and other pages for limitations. Repeating this for tens of results is annoying.

See an example below. Can you tell this is free or paid? When I tried to load a PDF after adding this, it showed some sort of error message (in broken English, so it was difficult what exactly it was saying) that this free version can only open PDF's < 4MB in size. The price was about $900. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10900489/108646187-6202e380-74f8-11eb-9f17-532143041526.png)

### Describe the solution you'd like
Why not have an entry like the following, as with the current "Version:", "Author(s)", "License:", etc?
Pricing: Free, $900 annual, $1000 one-time, etc
Free version limitation: Can't open PDF < 4MB in size, 30-day trial, watermark, etc. 

### Additional context
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Prepare documentation for embedded readme feature" (#8426) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
- [ ] Update error docs and nuspec/MSBuild reference - already finished by Advay https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/pull/2118#issuecomment-781447122
- [ ] Update best practices doc to include readme suggestion
- [ ] Add allowlist and general information about new Readme/documentation feature to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/publish-a-package

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[SAS Token] Create get only uri methods for files." (#8424) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Added new methods to retrieve the file/package uri. This will help us support sas tokens that are not generated on methods that returns an uri with the sas token embeded.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove logic with ImagesRewritten & remove the feature flag" (#8425) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8406#discussion_r568042833


ImagesRewritten [](start = 72, length = 15)

Since we are tightening validation for images in markdown, we can remove the 'ImagesRewritten' functionality after the allow list is stabilized.  

remove the feature flag since it will become default behavior

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Best practices for libraries with admin level dependencies" (#10589) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm looking for a little bit of guidance.

I have a set of .NET Framework driver libraries that have been distributed via an installer for many years now.  I'm now looking to modernize those libraries for easier consumption via NuGet packages for .NET 5 and beyond.  However, these .NET libraries have dependencies on things like a kernel mode driver and shared global configuration/data that require administrative privilege for initial installation.

Some of these dependencies (like the configuration data) can be localized, but some realistically cannot.  I know this type of global data is antithetical to NuGet, so I'll still need a traditional installer (although I'd be happy if there were some alternative here).

So, I think the best I can do is create a NuGet package _and_ require the user to run a traditional installer once.  One concern with this approach is ensuring the version of the NuGet package is compatible with the installed driver.

Are there any established best practices for this type of scenario?  Any examples of packages that have similar requirements?

I've thought of a couple of things that might work/help:
- Include a `.targets` file in the `build` folder of the NuGet package that is responsible for verifying that the driver is installed, and that the driver version is compatible
- Update our installer to publish a `.targets` file to [`MSBuildExtensionsPath`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/msbuild/customize-your-build?view=vs-2019#msbuildextensionspath-and-msbuilduserextensionspath) to define a custom property that can be used for the NuGet package version

Any thoughts or examples would be appreciated.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget pack includes files and directories beginning with dot (.), despite default excludes" (#10588) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This issue was closed as fixed in #8798 but is still occurring as of nuget.exe `5.9.0-preview.2` and `5.8.1`.

<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | Visual Studio | MSBuild.exe | dotnet.exe): *nuget.exe*

Product version: `5.9.0-preview.2` and `5.8.1`

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: *no*

## Repro steps and/or sample project

Repro: [repro.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/6018199/repro.zip)

Running `nuget pack` with both the latest stable and latest preview version will produce `WARNING: NU5119` but add dot-prefixed entries anyway.

`5.9.0-preview.2` also produces an exception of `The given key was not present in the dictionary`.

<!-- Please add as much details as possible to help us to reproduce your problem. -->

### Verbose Logs

#### With nuget.exe `5.9.0-preview.2`
```
> nuget pack LibDeflate.Native.nuspec -Verbosity detailed
NuGet Version: 5.9.0.6967
Attempting to build package from 'LibDeflate.Native.nuspec'.
WARNING: NU5119: File 'C:\Dropbox\Data\LocalRepos\LibDeflate.Native\.gitattributes' was not added to the package. Files and folders starting with '.' or ending with '.nupkg' are excluded by default. To include this file, use -NoDefaultExcludes from the commandline
WARNING: NU5119: File 'C:\Dropbox\Data\LocalRepos\LibDeflate.Native\.gitignore' was not added to the package. Files and folders starting with '.' or ending with '.nupkg' are excluded by default. To include this file, use -NoDefaultExcludes from the commandline
WARNING: NU5119: File 'C:\Dropbox\Data\LocalRepos\LibDeflate.Native\LibDeflate.Native.1.7.0.nupkg' was not added to the package. Files and folders starting with '.' or ending with '.nupkg' are excluded by default. To include this file, use -NoDefaultExcludes from the commandline
WARNING: NU5119: File 'C:\Dropbox\Data\LocalRepos\LibDeflate.Native\.dummy\LibDeflate.Native.1.7.0 - Copy.nupkg' was not added to the package. Files and folders starting with '.' or ending with '.nupkg' are excluded by default. To include this file, use -NoDefaultExcludes from the commandline
WARNING: NU5119: File 'C:\Dropbox\Data\LocalRepos\LibDeflate.Native\.vs\LibDeflate.Native\v16\.suo' was not added to the package. Files and folders starting with '.' or ending with '.nupkg' are excluded by default. To include this file, use -NoDefaultExcludes from the commandline
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet restore only tries one source" (#6140) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @keslerm on March 6, 2017 19:14_

> Œª  dotnet --version
> 1.0.0-rc4-004771

When using dotnet restore with either a nuget.config with multiple sources, or passing multiple -s options it only tries one source. 

This means that when trying to do dotnet restore on a project that has a private repo and a public repo and pulls from both, the restore operation will fail because obviously some package disparity between the two repos will exist.

Results from running:
    Œª  dotnet restore                                                                                                                                                                                                        
      Restoring packages for C:\Project\example.csproj...                                                                                                                                      
      Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsyncCore' for source 'https://privaterepo.com/FindPackagesById()?id='YamlDotNet.Signed''.                                                                     
      Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (Not Found).                                                                                                                                                       
      Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsyncCore' for source 'https://privaterepo.com/FindPackagesById()?id='WebSocketSharp''.                                                                        
      Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (Not Found).                                                                                                                                                       
      Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsyncCore' for source 'https://privaterepo.com/FindPackagesById()?id='EntityFramework.CodeFirstStoreFunctions''.                                               `

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/dotnet#361_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve error message when package is rejected by trusted signers configuration" (#10587) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: nuget.exe

Product version: v5.8.1

NuGet ignores packages that do not meet my trusted signers configuration. However, the error message for this scenario is unclear and unhelpful.

## Repro steps and/or sample project

`packages.config` file:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<packages>
  <package id="Newtonsoft.Json" version="12.0.1" targetFramework="net472" />
</packages>
```

`nuget.config` file:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <trustedSigners>
    <repository name="nuget.org" serviceIndex="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json">
      <certificate fingerprint="0E5F38F57DC1BCC806D8494F4F90FBCEDD988B46760709CBEEC6F4219AA6157D" hashAlgorithm="SHA256" allowUntrustedRoot="false" />
      <owners>jamesnk</owners>
    </repository>
  </trustedSigners>
</configuration>
```

Now run a restore. Notice my restore source is the DEV environment, but my trusted signers is for PROD environment:

```ps1
.\nuget581.exe restore .\Project\Project.csproj -Source https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3/index.json -PackagesDirectory packages
```

The output:

```
...
Restoring NuGet package Newtonsoft.Json.12.0.1.
  GET https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3/flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json/12.0.1/newtonsoft.json.12.0.1.nupkg
  OK https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3/flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json/12.0.1/newtonsoft.json.12.0.1.nupkg 166ms
Installing Newtonsoft.Json 12.0.1.
WARNING: Unable to find version '12.0.1' of package 'Newtonsoft.Json'.
  C:\Users\sharm\.nuget\packages\: Package 'Newtonsoft.Json.12.0.1' is not found on source 'C:\Users\sharm\.nuget\packages\'.
  https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3/index.json:

WARNING: Unable to find version '12.0.1' of package 'Newtonsoft.Json'.
  C:\Users\sharm\.nuget\packages\: Package 'Newtonsoft.Json.12.0.1' is not found on source 'C:\Users\sharm\.nuget\packages\'.
  https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3/index.json:


Errors in packages.config projects
    Unable to find version '12.0.1' of package 'Newtonsoft.Json'.
      C:\Users\sharm\.nuget\packages\: Package 'Newtonsoft.Json.12.0.1' is not found on source 'C:\Users\sharm\.nuget\packages\'.
      https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3/index.json:

...
```

Ideally the error message should explain the package wasn't installed due to trusted signers policy:

> NU1234: Package Newtonsoft.Json 12.0.1 could not be installed as it does not meet your trusted signers configuration.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet restore failing on .NET 5 for Debian-based OSes" (#49) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hey Everyone,

Our preliminary investigation shows that .NET 5 restore is broken for Debian-based operating systems including Docker thus resulting in error messages like:

```
error NU3037: Package 'System.Memory 4.5.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The author primary signature validity period has expired.
```

### [Debian Versions](https://www.debian.org/releases/)
- We're currently aware that Debian 10 ("buster") and earlier versions are affected. ‚ùå
- We do know that Debian testing ("bullseye") and later are not affected. ‚úî

This is because of an [issue reported](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=962596) in the `ca-certificates` package in which the root CA being used are not trusted and must be installed manually due to [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues). Because this issue has been resolved recently in version 20210119 of this package, it is not available in a Debian version as provided in `dotnet-docker` for `buster-slim` today.

## Workarounds

- Manually update the [ca-certificates](https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/ca-certificates) package to version 20210119 including a `bullseye` or later version.
- Consider using a different Debian-based Docker image such as `alpine` or `focal`.
 
## Solution

We're currently working to update the `dotnet-docker`'s `buster-slim` image to update the `ca-certificates` package to 20210119 that resolves this issue. We are however currently verifying this is a viable solution with no large diffs between the `buster` and `bullseye` releases.

Additionally, the `ca-certificates` package is due to be installed in the Debian FTP archive which will promote this fix to the `buster` release in the next few days to which an updated `buster-slim` image will be prepared and released when available.

## Stay Updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We'll continue to update the discussion at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10491.
- We will also continue posting updates on https://status.nuget.org and on Twitter @NuGet.
